title: Yin Haiguang
text:
Yin Haiguang (; 5 December 1919 – 16 September 1969) was a <a href="Chinese%20people">Chinese</a> author, educator and philosopher from <a href="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>.
Biography.
Yin was born to missionary parents in <a href="Huanggang">Huanggang</a>, <a href="Hubei">Hubei</a> in December 1919 and was raised in <a href="Wuchang%20District">Wuchang</a>. His uncle, Yin Ziheng (), was a revolutionist who took part in <a href="Xinhai%20Revolution">Xinhai Revolution</a>.
At the age of 13, he studied at Wuchang Middle School (). When he was a high school student, he started to be interested in philosophy. Before he reached the age of 20, he translated a textbook on logic, which ran more than 400 pages, from English to Chinese. He helped introduce Western thinkers and philosophers such as Bertrand Russell, Karl Popper and Frederick von Hayek to liberal Chinese intellectuals. <a href="Jin%20Yuelin">Jin Yuelin</a> had a strong influence on his youth.
In 1938, he entered <a href="Southwest%20Associated%20University">Southwest Associated University</a>, majoring in <a href="philosophy">philosophy</a>. In 1942, He was accepted to <a href="Tsinghua%20University">Tsinghua University</a> and graduated in 1945. Upon his graduation, he joined the Youth Army. returned to <a href="Chongqing">Chongqing</a> after eight months.
In 1946, he worked in <a href="Central%20Daily%20News">Central Daily News</a> as an editor. Meanwhile, he taught philosophy at <a href="University%20of%20Nanking">the University of Nanking</a>.
In 1949, along with the relocation of Central Daily News, Yin settled in <a href="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>. He began teaching philosophy at <a href="National%20Taiwan%20University">National Taiwan University</a> and became an editor of the semi-monthly "<a href="Free%20China%20Journal">Free China Journal</a> (FCJ)". Along with other intellectuals from his circle, Yin used the FCJ to publish articles that were at times highly critical of the Kuomintang. In 1960, the authorities lost patience and shut down the FCJ. A crackdown followed which led to Yin being banned from teaching and lecturing. After that, he withdrew from public life.
In 1954, Yin went to <a href="Harvard%20University">Harvard University</a> as a visiting scholar and returned to Taiwan the year after. However, he suffered from <a href="political%20persecution">political persecution</a> since then. In 1969, Yin died of <a href="gastric%20cancer">gastric cancer</a> when he was 49.
Since 2003, the <a href="http%3A//www.yin.org.tw">house</a> in which he lived in Taipei, near Taiwan National University, has been listed as a historic landmark and can be visited by the public.
Personal life.
In October 1953, Yin married Xia Junlu (; d. 2013), he had a daughter Yin Wenli (; b. March 1956). His daughter and son-in-law now live in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>.
